articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: This bulletin from an astronomical club details a busy period filled with upcoming events like the Messier Marathon, Astronomy Day, and various star parties. It also announces significant club personnel changes, including a new treasurer and publicity chairperson, and reports on past observing sessions. The document serves as a comprehensive update on club activities, member contributions, and important dates for observers.

articles.title: AANC Messier Club
articles.summary: The AANC Messier Club encourages amateur astronomers to engage in observational astronomy by identifying Messier objects. It offers a plaque for observing all 107 Messier objects and a parchment for spotting 75 or more. Participants must register, use their own instruments (with some exceptions), and record their observations within a two-year period.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: Despite no new comet discoveries or recoveries this year, Comet Bradfield (1979L), discovered in late 1979, remains visible in the Northern Hemisphere. Observers have reported a short tail and a coma currently about 10 arcminutes across, expected to shrink to 3-4 arcminutes by early March as it moves away from Earth and the Sun.

articles.title: Comet Bradfield (1979L)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Bradfield (1979L) for late February and early March 1980. It lists the comet's right ascension, declination, and estimated magnitude for various dates, with the data sourced from IAU Circular 3443.

articles.title: Comets In Their Eyes
articles.summary: This article profiles two notable amateur astronomers known for their comet discoveries: Pierre Mechain (1744-1804) and Jack Bennett (1915-). Mechain, a contemporary of Charles Messier, discovered eight comets and 22 Messier objects, while Bennett, an active modern-day hunter, is credited with two comets, including the well-known Comet Bennett of 1969/70. Both demonstrate significant contributions to astronomy despite not being professional astronomers.

articles.title: On The Use Of Astronomical Films And Plates
articles.summary: The article humorously suggests an impending 'photon crisis' in astrophotography, stemming from a constant total starlight supply divided among an increasing number of telescopes. To counter this, it proposes a radical shift to 'dark sensitive films' and plates, which would be more efficient for the predominantly dark astrophotography, allow daylight processing, and even enable the direct imaging of elusive black holes.

articles.title: ASTROPHOTOGRAPHY
articles.summary: This article serves as an introductory guide to astrophotography, outlining various methods suitable for different skill levels and equipment. It describes techniques ranging from simple 'camera on tripod' for bright objects to advanced 'prime focus' for deep-sky targets, detailing the equipment, exposure times, and suitable celestial subjects for each. The author, Robert Fingerhut, encourages beginners, promises future in-depth articles on specific methods, and offers assistance to those interested in learning astrophotography.

articles.title: WALTER SCOTT HOUSTON
articles.summary: Walter Scott Houston, a prominent figure in amateur astronomy, began his journey in grammar school with a homemade telescope, observing all Messier objects. He made significant contributions to the AAVSO, pioneered celestial navigation methods in the Army, and wrote the popular "Deep Sky Wonders" column for Sky & Telescope. His diverse interests included variable star observation, solar flare detection, and meteorite hunting, and he strongly advocated for amateur astronomers to engage in meaningful scientific contributions.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on meridian PST
articles.summary: The document provides a detailed schedule listing dates and times in Pacific Standard Time (PST) when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will be on the central meridian. This observational guide covers a period from late February through the end of March, offering specific windows for viewing this prominent feature.

articles.title: RIVERSIDE TELESCOPE MAKERS CONFERENCE
articles.summary: The 12th annual Riverside Telescope Makers Conference (RTMC) is scheduled for May 24-26 at Camp Oakes, near Big Bear City. The event offers weekend lodging, meals, and camping options, alongside a registration fee, with reservations due by May 15th. Activities include merit awards for telescope making and astrophotography, a swap meet, recreational opportunities, and welcomes prospective speakers.
